title: From Coughlin to Carnegie
text:

Join the Conversation Miranda Klein , mquartemon@thetowntalk.com, (318) 487-6354 2:05 p.m. CDT October 22, 2015 Buy Photo Elisa D'Auria of Italy practices before her scheduled performance in the first round of the Louisiana International Piano Competition held Wednesday at the Coughlin-Saunders Performing Arts Center. (Photo: Melinda Martinez/The Town Talk) Buy Photo 33 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The talents of 19 pianists from eight countries took center stage at the Coughlin-Saunders Performing Arts Center this week. 
The sixth biennial Louisiana International Piano Competition brought contestants from Canada, China, France, Georgia, Italy, Russia, South Korea and the United States to Alexandria. The prizes for those three winners this year include thousands of dollars in cash and the opportunity to perform in Carnegie Hall. The musicians, ranging in age from 19-35, competed all day Tuesday and Wednesday, vying for a spot among eight semifinalists, and eventually, three finalists. 
For the first rounds, each competitor played a 30-minute program, which consisted of pieces by Bach, Chopin, Liszt and other classical composers. 
Semifinalist announcements were made on Wednesday night, and the second rounds of the competition went on Thursday. 
Nina Bakradze, from the country of Georgia, Solomon Eichner of Baltimore and Alexander Kostritsa of Russia sat together and anxiously awaited hearing the first deliberations. 
Kostritsa, 27, said it wasn't the kind of anxiousness he felt before playing earlier in the day, though. 
"It's a different kind of nervousness," Kostritsa said. Buy Photo 
Simon Xu of France practices before his scheduled performance in the first round of the Louisiana International Piano Competition held Wednesday at the Coughlin-Saunders Performing Arts Center. (Photo: Melinda Martinez/The Town Talk) 
Eichner, 26, said he was trying not to think too hard about his Tuesday performance yet. 
"I'm always very critical about my playing, so I try not to think about too many details," he said. 
In addition to playing for a panel of jurors, the pianists had local audiences both days. Bakradze, Eichner and Kostritsa all said that is something they welcomed. 
"It's better with people," Bakradze, 31, said of competing. "It feels more like a concert." 
Bakradze also performed on Wednesday after two hours of warm-up time. She, much like the other 18 contestants, had spent most of her time in Louisiana so far recovering from jet lag and practicing as many hours as possible in hopes of advancing. 
"Because you don't know," she said of who will make it past round one. "If you pass, you need those hours." 
In Bakradze's case, she did. She was among the eight semifinalists announced Wednesday night. The other seven included Moye Chen, Elisa D'Auri, Connie Kim-Sheng, Saetbyeol Kim, Hao Liu, Yuri Noh and Gregory Wang. 
After the announcement, all 19 contestants and the host families in whose homes they stayed were invited to a reception at the River Oaks Square Arts Center. 
Bakradze suddenly had other plans, though. 
"I will go practice right away," she said of what was next on her agenda. 
The same went for the other semifinalists as well. That's just part of their recipe for success. 
"Musicians don't eat, don't sleep, don't rest, and then they play," Bakradze explained with a laugh.
